comments.content: Agree, someone copied these answers into question 187 from question 189 which is asking how to delete the NTP peer. The real answers for question 187 are not shown.
I absolutely agree. BUT the only possible parameter is state: absent ;-)

discussion.content: Should be missing option "state: present"
state: present

Selected Answer: A
Correct answer: A 

state: present or absent 
state: string
Manage the state of the resource.
Choices:
 present ← (default)
 absent

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/cisco/ios/ios_ntp_module.html

comments.content:
Just to add to this, there isn't any "config" option in the ios_ntp module... so it has to state: absent.

The module is deprecated now any though so maybe the question won't appear.

state: present or absent 
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/cisco/ios/ios_ntp_module.html

state 
string

Manage the state of the resource.

present ← (default)
absent

questions.question_text:
A developer needs to configure an environment to orchestrate and configure.
Which two tools should be used for each task? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: BE correct

Selected Answer: BE
terraform for environment and ansible for configuration. with k8s you will deploy the apps, but on top of the env already created

Selected Answer: BE
BE is correct one

comments.content: K8 only orquestate docker, Terraform has a wide scope
Asked ChatGPT too, i got B&E this time, but your answer also seems correct

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
According to ChatGPT, the answer is D & E
How confident are you in your answer?
I am highly confident in my answer. Kubernetes is a widely-used and popular open-source tool for container orchestration, and it can help automate the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications. Ansible is a popular open-source configuration management tool, it can help automate software provisioning, configuration management, and application deployment. Ansible is able to interact with a wide variety of systems and platforms, making it a great tool for configuring and provisioning multiple hosts in parallel.

Selected Answer: BE
Correct answers: B & E

Orchestration tools
Ansible
NSO
Kubernetes (but this one is correct as well) 
Terraform

Configuration Tools
Ansible
Puppet
Chef
SaltStack 
SCCM

CI/DC Pipeline Orchestrators 
Jenkins

Selected Answer: BE
Orchestration tools
Ansible

Kubernetes (but this one is correct as well)

Selected Answer: DE
Kubernetes Orchestration https://kubernetes.io/
ANsible for config: https://www.ansible.com/

What the heck is this question? Kubernetes is an orchestration tool. There are plenty of resources (including RedHat itself) stating that ansible is both an orchestration and configuration tool. This is an absolutely shitty question.

comments.content: I personally would go with D&E

discussion.content:
I think A should be the correct answer.

https://developer.cisco.com/docs/ios-xe/#!ansible-quick-start-guide/hosts-file

Selected Answer: A
Correct answer: A 

[ios-xe:vars]
ansible_network_os=ios
ansible_connection=network_cli

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/network/user_guide/network_best_practices_2.5.html
https://developer.cisco.com/docs/ios-xe/#!ansible-quick-start-guide/hosts-file

Selected Answer: A
The correct answer is A.
cat /etc/ansible/hosts

[ios-xe:vars]
ansible_network_os=ios
ansible_connection=network_cli
https://developer.cisco.com/docs/ios-xe/#!ansible-quick-start-guide/authentication

Selected Answer: A
Definitely network_cli (A)

Selected Answer: A
The following variables are common for all platforms in the inventory, though they can be overwritten for a particular inventory group or host.

ansible_connection
Ansible uses the ansible-connection setting to determine how to connect to a remote device. When working with Ansible Networking, set this to an appropriate network connection option, such as``ansible.netcommon.network_cli``, so Ansible treats the remote node as a network device with a limited execution environment. Without this setting, Ansible would attempt to use ssh to connect to the remote and execute the Python script on the network device, which would fail because Python generally isn’t available on network devices.
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/network/user_guide/network_best_practices_2.5.html
A answer
It is A. The only possible solution!

Selected Answer: A
Regarding the following, I will select A as the correct answer.
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/network/user_guide/platform_ios.html#connections-available

Selected Answer: A
network_cli is the correct option in ansible

I think is A, network_cli is the only correct option for the ansible_connection variable.
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/network/getting_starte/network_differences.html
network_cli is used for secure connectivity to network devices. SSH is intended to connect to servers. https://yetiops.net/posts/ansible-for-networking-part-3-cisco-ios/
A is only used in test environment never in production as it poses a threat. Therefore it is common to use SSH

comments.content:
Your right with A.

Ansible uses the ansible-connection setting to determine how to connect to a remote device. When working with Ansible Networking, set this to an appropriate network connection option, such as``ansible.netcommon.network_cli``, so Ansible treats the remote node as a network device with a limited execution environment. Without this setting, Ansible would attempt to use ssh to connect to the remote and execute the Python script on the network device, which would fail because Python generally isn’t available on network devices.
